channel.title: Wine question
channel.description:
So lately I've been missing Photoshop and TF2 so I've been messing around with Wine to see what I can get going on. Every tutorial I've seen about this stuff talks about installing it, but I don't want to reinstall the files onto my Linux partition. I was hoping someone knows a way to use Wine with programs on another partition/hard drive. Steam is installed on my F drive, as where Linux is on my L drive. Photoshop is on my C drive. I tried setting up everything that the tutorial says but not reinstalling it onto my Linux partition as it's drive is currently something like 20 GB. Anyone have any tips/advice for this?
-Holic

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Holic:

I’ll look into Windows and ext3 filesystems.

http://www.fs-driver.org/

Works great!

Read full topic

item.title: Wine question
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Ah ok thanks, I missed that. That really sucks, so as far as I know I can’t share my steam install with both OSes (Windows and Ubuntu).
I’ll look into Windows and ext3 filesystems.

-Holic

Read full topic

item.title: Wine question
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You can’t run steam on an NTFS partition, as stated here:

[quote=“http://appdb.winehq.org/objectManager.php?sClass=version&iId=1554”]Steam will not work from ntfs partition mounted using ntfs-3g driver.

This is a known limitation of the driver. Steam requires functionality (mmap with shared write access) which Wine can not emulate if it’s not supported on file system. To fix: Install Steam and all content into native Linux file system.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Wine question
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Great thanks! Makes sense, Photoshop is sorta running. Slow, buggy, but it’s working.
Steam fails but I’m sure I can get it working…

err:virtual:map_file_into_view shared writable mmap not supported, broken filesystem? err:virtual:NtMapViewOfSection map_file_into_view 0x760000 16b000 000000000 failed

Thanks again Mopar,
-Holic

Read full topic

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Symbolic links can be your best friend for things like that.
